questions.question: A complete sentence ends with a ______.
questions.explanation: Most sentences end with a full stop (.).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: A run-on sentence has too many _____ without stops.
questions.explanation: A run-on sentence has multiple ideas joined together without any full stop or a comma.

questions.question: Which is a complete sentence?
questions.explanation: This has a subject (I) and a predicate (bounce), making it a complete thought.

questions.question: Which is a fragment?
questions.explanation: This is a fragment because it doesn't have a subject.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: A good sentence needs a subject and a ____.
questions.explanation: Every complete sentence needs a subject (who or what) and a predicate (the action).

questions.question: Which is a run-on sentence?

options.text: We sing songs we dance we have fun.

questions.explanation: This is a run-on because it has multiple complete thoughts without any comma or a full stop.

questions.question: Which sentence is correct?
questions.explanation: This sentence starts with a capital letter and ends with a full stop.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: A _____ is a short, incomplete sentence.
questions.explanation: A fragment is an incomplete sentence missing important parts.

questions.question: Which is not a run-on sentence?

options.text: I like apples I like bananas I like oranges.
Apples are red bananas are yellow.

questions.explanation: This sentence correctly joins two ideas with 'and'.

questions.question: Which is a complete sentence?
questions.explanation: This has a subject (Elephants) and a predicate (eat), making it a complete thought.

questions.question: Which is a fragment?
questions.explanation: This is a fragment because it doesn't have a subject.

questions.question: Which sentence needs fixing?

options.text: She reads books she writes stories.

questions.explanation: This is a run-on sentence and needs a comma or a full stop between the two thoughts.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: A sentence tells a complete ____.
questions.explanation: A sentence expresses a complete idea or thought.

questions.question: Which is a complete sentence?
questions.explanation: This has a subject (Children) and a predicate (laugh), making it a complete thought.

questions.question: Which is a run-on sentence?

options.text: The moon is pretty it shines at night.

questions.explanation: This is a run-on because it has two complete thoughts without any full stop or a comma.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: A _____ sentence has too many ideas stuck together.
questions.explanation: A run-on sentence incorrectly joins multiple complete thoughts.

questions.question: Which is not a complete sentence?
questions.explanation: This is a fragment because it doesn't have a subject.

questions.question: Which sentence is correct?
questions.explanation: This sentence starts with a capital letter and ends with a full stop.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: A good writer uses complete _____ to share ideas.
questions.explanation: Complete sentences help writers express their ideas clearly.

questions.question: Which is a fragment?
questions.explanation: This is a fragment because it doesn't have a subject or a predicate.
